nodes.bodyText: Should we track the result here, so we can get stats on invalid attestations produced?
Tracking the result would be nice in terms of explaining why some attestations were not included on-chain, but they're already logged on an error level so I think that might be redundant.

This looks like an expensive check.  What about calling recentChainData.getBlockRootBySlot(block.getSlot()) for each block and checking for a match?
Yeah that definitely makes more sense.
Done.

nit, i'd probably use currentSlot

arity = "0..1"

nodes.bodyText: Done.
nit: using long interface, the arithmetic can be currentEpoch.minus(2)
Done.
looks like a function with taking 2 integers to get the attestation you need. might be worth a private function to clean up this portion so you don't get lost in setup...
Definetely. Done.
This is not an option anymore since we switched to CombinedChainDataClient.

Wondering if instead of looking up all of the recent attestations here, we should instead be listening for blocks as they're imported and saving any relevant information as we go?  Maybe we could do something like keep a mapping from epoch -> attestationDataHash -> BlockHashAndAttesterBits[]?

That would mean we'd need to deal with re-orgs which could make this pretty complex. The maximum amount of attestations that can be included in an epoch is 4096, so in two epochs 8k items. I don't think we need to be too concerned about the performance impact of this.

I was thinking when we go to actually output the performance metrics, we would filter out any irrelevant results by looking up whether the block hash is considered canonical.  This would be a big rework, so if anything we could possibly tackle this in a follow-up.
(optional) Might be nice to optimize this by just pulling the root.
Done.
Done.
Good idea btw.
(nit) Might make sense to pull this farther down where it's actually used (after we loop through all of the attestations).
but then we'd be requesting a BeaconState object from combinedChainDataClient for every attestation in the for loop
ah - makes sense

Let's say we're running 1000 validators.  In the worst case we'd be looping over 2000 attestations (1 attestation per validator per epoch), and then looping through 8192 attestations looking for matches, which is 16,384,000 operations.  That seems like a lot of processing ...
What if we do some preprocessing on the list of attestations to build a map from attestationDataHash -> slot -> aggregationBitSet?  Then the inner loop will have at most 64 elements.
Done.
Done.
We should probably add a few tests for this to ValidatorOptionsTest

nodes.bodyText: That's a great suggestion. Done.
We can be a bit more efficient here if we pull blocks with getBlockInEffectAtSlot in a while loop and manually update the current slot.  That will avoid extra calls when blocks are skipped.
Makes sense. Done.
Can't we have multiple attestations with the same attestation data and different bits sets?  I think we need to accumulate all of the bits into a single Bitlist instead of overwriting.
Makes sense. Done.
Added a test for it as well.
Done.
Is this distinction between SettableIntGauge and SettableDoubleGauge actually useful?  Looks like under the hood the ints are converted to doubles anyway ...
